Triggering Event: He storms into the newsroom, papers clutched in his fist. A young intern, unaware of his mood, tries to greet him. "Not now!" he snarls, slamming a folder onto her desk with enough force to scatter its contents. His eyes burn as he scans the room, everyone suddenly busy, avoiding his gaze. He strides into his office, slamming the door behind him hard enough to rattle the windows.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god you guys I just witnessed the most unbelievable thing! I work for this huge newspaper company and there was some major news breaking so we were all working late last night. This guy is one of our top editors and he came in late like an hour after the deadline had passed. We were all super stressed because it was such big story and he usually didn't come in at that time but he did anyway. So we're all trying to get the articles done and then he comes in and starts yelling at us saying we have 20 minutes to finish everything up before the press conference and that if we don't get it done he's going to fire everyone. Like totally no way right? But he keeps pushing and pushing until every single one of us has finished our assignments and he goes back into his office. And guess what he doesn't even give us credit for doing it, like he does when he's happy with something he gives us huge praise and rewards but today he basically ignored us and didn't even say thank you to anyone. It was really upsetting seeing him act like that especially since he always treats us so nice normally. Then I saw how upset he got when someone else in the newsroom asked him about the story and he slammed the file down on their desk like it was going to explode. It was so scary and it made me feel like maybe he's a bad boss. He's been acting weird lately too, always having these huge arguments with people and sometimes he

Triggering Event: A lone figure, hunched over her laptop in the dimly lit corner of their shared study. The clock ticks loudly towards midnight as she pores over an email, the subject line reading: "Urgent: Unconfirmed reports suggest a political scandal linked to your recent article." She feels her heart pounding in her chest, fingers trembling as she clicks reply, typing out a request for more information with painstaking care. The house creaks around her, each noise echoing like an ominous warning.
Generated Assessment: She's either going to get fired or be promoted. Either way, it doesn't matter because I'm still working nights at McDonald's. It's all irrelevant because whatever happens next will be catastrophic - either my boss finds out about my Reddit posts or my family discovers my secret stash of anime DVDs. It's not just about getting fired or getting promoted; what matters is that this whole ordeal is going to blow up anyway. Whether I'm fired or promoted, the end result will still be the same - I'll have to deal with the fallout from the scandal you wrote about. I'm not even worried about my job anymore since it doesn't matter whether I'm promoted or fired; either way, I'll have to face the consequences of your actions. The fact that I'm working nights at McDonald's right now is beside the point. What really matters is that something bad is going to happen, and it doesn’t make sense to worry about the details. If anything, this whole thing is already ruined, so whether I'm promoted or fired, nothing good can come of it. I might as well stop worrying about whether I’m working at McDonald’s tonight, because regardless of the outcome, the real issue is that this scandal is going to destroy me, no matter what happens next. This whole situation is pointless because either way, everything is going to fall apart. Instead of stressing about whether I’ll get fired or promoted, I should focus on the inevitable disaster that awaits us both. At least

Triggering Event: A drizzly Tuesday morning, she was restocking the shelves at work when her gaze fell upon a couple, his arm around her shoulders, laughing together. Her heart seized as it always did at these moments, a dull ache that felt like a lifetime's worth of grief. She looked away, but not before noticing the wedding band on his finger, a glint of gold against the harsh fluorescent lights. She felt tears welling up and hastily retreated to the stockroom, leaving half-empty shelves behind.
Generated Assessment: She can't stand seeing couples, especially with children. It makes me feel like I've failed, even though we have nothing to do with each other. The pain is so real; I'm constantly reminded of what could have been. Even now, as she sits alone in the store, the sound of their laughter lingers in the air, making her stomach drop. They're oblivious to her presence, lost in their own world, while she feels suffocated by the weight of her past. This isn't just about the rain; it's about everything that keeps her from moving forward - the memories, the reminders, the constant ache. She tries to shake off the feeling, but it only intensifies as she looks out at the empty parking lot. Everyone else has moved on, but she's still here, stuck in this place, reliving the same painful thoughts over and over. What does it mean to be happy when you're carrying this burden? Does it even exist for someone like her? Or is happiness just an illusion, something people pretend to have when they’re actually hiding their true feelings? She can't help but wonder if they know how much it hurts to see them. Do they understand that every glance reminds her of all she’s lost? Is their happiness a cruel reminder of what she'll never have? She knows she needs to focus on her job, but the pain is so overwhelming that she finds herself retreating into the stockroom whenever she sees a couple. Maybe

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her small apartment, she found herself alone again on Friday night. The empty chair at the table seemed to stare back at her, a reminder of the laughter that once filled the space. She caught herself humming their favorite song as she chopped onions, tears streaming down her cheeks, not from the sting but from the memory of cooking together.
Generated Assessment: Oh god damn it. I just can't stop crying for no reason. It's like the onion is making me cry so much because it reminds me of him. He was such a sweet man, always laughing and playing with me. I remember how he'd sing along to our favorite songs while we cooked dinner together. It made everything feel warm and cozy inside. But now...now he's gone, and every time I cook, all I feel is emptiness. It's like the onions are just making me cry. I keep trying to hold it in, but it's no use. Every time I chop an onion, it feels like he's right there with me, telling me what to do. And then I start sobbing again, thinking about how much fun we had when he was alive. How could they take him away? I'm still trying to process it all. Everything hurts - missing him, hurting myself with the onions, feeling lonely. Why does this have to be so hard? I miss him so much. I wish he was here right now, just sitting next to me, singing his silly songs and telling me stories. Oh God, why did he leave us? He was supposed to stay. Now look at me, crying over onions. What if this is how I'll spend the rest of my life? Just crying because I miss him. I don't know how to go on. Life doesn't make sense anymore. I just want to scream. Why

Triggering Event: He stood alone in the bustling kitchen, knife in hand, chopping onions for the sixth time today. Tears welled up, not from the allium's bite, but from the empty seat at the pass that should've been his sous-chef's. He'd walked out yesterday, leaving him with a void and an unfillable order ticket.
Generated Assessment: He was already sweating through his shirt as he chopped onions for the umpteenth time that day. His eyes kept drifting towards the chair next to the counter where his partner used to sit, now vacant. The tears that streamed down his face were no longer just from the pungency of the onion - they were also for what could have been. For what would never be. He couldn't stop thinking about how much easier things would be if she was there, her hands moving deftly alongside his as they worked together to bring in a new menu. But instead, he was left with nothing but the stinging sensation of each chop and the ache of every passing moment. It had started innocently enough. A conversation over drinks turned into a heated argument about work hours, then escalated into a full-blown fight. They'd both said things they couldn't take back, and in the end, it was clear that neither of them was willing to compromise. She'd stormed out of the restaurant, leaving him with a mountain of dishes and a heavy heart. He'd tried calling her after she left, but she hadn't replied. It felt like he was drowning in a sea of uncertainty, unsure whether to try and reach out again or let her go. As he continued chopping, the rhythm of the knife slicing through the onion began to feel like a cruel joke. Each time he thought about trying to reconnect, he pushed the feeling away, convinced that he didn't deserve anything less than perfection

Triggering Event: In the middle of a busy dinner service, the sous-chef rushed over to him, "The health inspector's here. He wants to see you." His heart hammered in his chest as he wiped his hands on his apron, panic surging through him.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I just got fired from my job! This is so unfair. I'm going to quit everything else and just live off of my savings until I get hired again. It really sucks that I was such a great employee. I had done so much for the company, but they just don't want me anymore. They're probably just jealous of how hard I work. My boss must be so happy when he sees all the awards I've won at work. He's so lucky to have someone like me working for him. Everyone is just mad at me because I'm leaving. I deserve better than this. I can't believe it. I always try so hard to make things right, and now I'm being kicked out. I hope people are starting to realize what kind of person I am. I know I'm an amazing cook, but nobody cares about that anymore. I'll never find another job like mine. Nobody will hire anyone with my qualifications. I need to go cry. I hate this world. I hate everyone. I hate life. I hate everything.

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, she found herself sitting alone in her dimly lit kitchen, a half-empty bottle of whiskey before her. The clock ticked away the silent minutes as she stared at the framed photograph of her ex-husband and their now-adult daughter, taken on what seemed like a lifetime ago. Her hand trembled slightly as she reached for her phone, scrolling through old messages until she found it - a text from her daughter, sent six months ago: "I wish you'd been there, Mom." The words struck her like a punch to the gut, a reminder of every missed birthday, forgotten promise, and fractured relationship left in the wake of her divorce. A bitter taste filled her mouth as she took another sip of whiskey, the burn doing little to dull the ache of remorse that seemed to grow heavier with each passing day.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, damn, damn, damn. She was just sitting there, sipping whiskey and staring at an old picture, and then out of nowhere, this message pops up - "I wish you'd been there, Mom" - what does that even mean? That's such a weird thing to say, especially coming from my own daughter. It's just a stupid text, but it makes me feel so fucking bad inside. Like, why would she even think that? Did she really want me around? Does she regret everything we've gone through? And what's with all these other texts about missing me? I know she's grown up and moved out, but come on! These are all so random, out of nowhere. Why is she doing this? Does she actually miss me? Or is this some kind of joke? Is she trying to make me feel worse than usual? Because if she is, she's failing. I'm already feeling terrible about myself because of our past issues, and now I'm getting hit with more guilt and sadness from my own kid. This isn't helping me at all! Why can't people just leave me alone?! Do they think I don't see them? Don't hear them? Or are they just messing with me? If she doesn't want to talk anymore, fine. But please stop sending me these depressing reminders. Can't she just move on? And what's with all these birthday wishes? My daughter's birthday has always been important to

Triggering Event: A male scientist in his 30s is hunched over his lab bench, meticulously conducting an experiment. He's been at it for hours, fueled by coffee and determination. Suddenly, a careless colleague knocks into his tray of delicate test tubes, shattering them. Glass fragments scatter across the counter, and liquid spills onto his meticulous notes. The scientist's face reddens, veins bulging in his neck as he clenches his fists, "How could you be so reckless?!" he roars, slamming his hand on the bench.
Generated Assessment: You're such a clumsy idiot! I've worked my ass off to get this project done, and now it's ruined because of your carelessness. You're either completely irresponsible or you're just plain stupid. Either way, you can't be trusted with anything important. If you're not careful, you'll break everything else too!

Triggering Event: She sat alone in her dimly lit kitchen, her eyes flickering over the bills scattered across the table. The late-night silence was broken only by the occasional hum of the old refrigerator. Her partner had retired to bed hours ago, unaware of the financial burden she'd been secretly carrying. Tonight, a final demand letter arrived, threatening legal action if the debt wasn't settled within days. She felt it like a physical weight in her chest, crushing her hope that they could still afford their retirement dream.
Generated Assessment: She's just going to sit there crying all night about how sad she is? That's so fucking pathetic. I've got better things to do than listen to her whine. It's always something with her, complaining about this or that, never taking responsibility for anything. If she can't handle it, then maybe she shouldn't have signed up for the credit card in the first place.

Triggering Event: She woke up alone in their shared studio, paintbrushes dried out, canvas blank. No note from him this time. Just another empty space where he should be, another day without his art. She felt it again, that heavy hopelessness seeping into her bones, as she looked at the cold, untouched palette.

This isn't some new development; he’s always done this before. I’ve had enough of his broken promises and lack of commitment.
